core

Class GameObject

  • java.lang.Object
    • core.GameObject

  • public class GameObject
extends java.lang.Object
    If you would like to create a new entity which has it's own position, mesh or any other properties, you should create a new GameObject. A GameObjct can store any number of Components, including cameras, meshes and materials, splines, light sources etc. Of course you can create youe own Component. It also offers parent-child relations between GameObjects.
    See Also:
    Component

      • addChild

        public boolean addChild(@NotNull
                        GameObject child)
        Adds the given GameObject to this GameObject's children. The parameter can't be this, null, the ancestor of this or child of this.
        Parameters:
        child - add to children
        Returns:
        true if the parameter added successfully to the children, false otherwise

      • setParent

        public boolean setParent(@Nullable
                         GameObject parent)
        Sets the given GameObject to this GameObject's parent. The parameter can't be this, the descendant of this or the parent of this.
        Parameters:
        parent - parent
        Returns:
        true if the parameter set successfully to the parent of this, false otherwise

      • addComponent

        public boolean addComponent(@NotNull
                            Component component)
        Adds the given Component to this GameObject.
        Parameters:
        component - component
        Returns:
        false if the GameObject already contained the given Component, true otherwise
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - Component can't be null
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - you can't assign a Component to multiple GameObjects

public <T> java.util.List<T> getComponents(@NotNull
